national_context.title: Unprecedented National Scale
national_context.summary: The biggest local government shake-up since 1974. All 21 remaining two-tier county areas simultaneously reorganising — 180+ councils facing abolition.
national_context.legal_basis: Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007

key_facts.label: Not in Labour's manifesto
key_facts.detail: Labour's 2024 manifesto pledged devolution via a 'Take Back Control Bill' but did not mention abolishing district or county councils. The reorganisation plan emerged in the December 2024 White Paper, five months after the election.

key_facts.label: 30 elections cancelled
key_facts.detail: 30 council elections cancelled nationally for May 2026, including 7 in Lancashire (Burnley, Chorley, Hyndburn, Pendle, Preston, West Lancashire, Blackburn with Darwen). The Electoral Commission called this 'unprecedented' and warned of a 'clear conflict of interest in asking existing Councils to decide how long it will be before they are answerable to voters.'

key_facts.label: Reform UK legal challenge
key_facts.detail: Reform UK launched a High Court challenge against the cancellation of 29 council elections, arguing it undermines democratic accountability.

key_facts.label: No precedent at this scale
key_facts.detail: The last time a government reorganised all of England's local government simultaneously was the Local Government Act 1972. The 1995-98 Banham review, 2009 Labour reforms, and 2019-23 Conservative reforms were all selective and voluntary.

key_facts.label: International outlier
key_facts.detail: The top-down, rapid, universal approach is unusual among European democracies. Denmark (2007), Sweden (1974), and France use consensus-based models. English local government has no constitutional protection — it exists entirely at the pleasure of Parliament.

proposed_models.name: Two Unitaries
proposed_models.description: Divides Lancashire broadly along the River Ribble into North and South. LCC's preferred option — the only model where all authorities meet the government's 500,000 population threshold.

authorities.name: North Lancashire
authorities.notes: Historic Lancaster, Fylde Coast tourism, Preston as admin capital, rural Ribble Valley. Includes existing Blackpool unitary.

authorities.name: South Lancashire
authorities.notes: East Lancashire mill towns, commuter belt, Blackburn with Darwen unitary. Diverse mix of urban deprivation and affluent suburbs.

political_analysis.likely_control: Labour majority — combines 4 Labour-majority districts with 2 Labour coalitions, Blackburn Labour, plus Conservative Wyre/Fylde/RV and Green-led Lancaster
political_analysis.councillor_reduction: From ~604 combined (district + county) to ~160 (est. 80 per authority). 73% fewer elected representatives.
political_analysis.who_benefits: Lancashire County Council preserves its geographic footprint across the largest possible area. Reform UK (who control LCC) would benefit from county-wide name recognition but would lose county-level seats.
political_analysis.who_loses: District council leaders lose all their seats. East Lancashire communities (Burnley, Pendle, Hyndburn, Rossendale) lose distinct identity — merged with geographically distant Chorley, West Lancs, Blackburn.

strengths: Only model where ALL authorities exceed 500K population threshold
Highest projected annual savings — both CCN (£21.2M) and AI DOGE independent model (£24.8M)
Lowest per-authority transition cost
Simplest governance structure — fewest boundaries, fewest IT integrations
Maximum economies of scale in back-office, procurement, senior management
Academic evidence: 2 authorities of 722K and 880K still within performance range (Andrews & Boyne 2009 found diseconomies above ~500K but effects are modest up to ~800K)
weaknesses: Very large authorities — risk of remote decision-making (councillor:resident ratio of ~1:4,500-5,500)
Burnley/Pendle grouped with Chorley/West Lancs despite no geographic or economic connection
Mixes highly deprived areas (Burnley, Blackburn) with affluent areas in same authority — risk of cross-subsidisation resentment
80% of Burnley/Pendle survey respondents opposed merger with Blackburn with Darwen
South Lancashire at 880K approaches the diseconomy threshold identified in academic literature

Blackpool gains critical mass with Preston and Fylde

ccn_critique.title: Why You Should Question the CCN/PwC Numbers
ccn_critique.summary: The CCN is a lobby group for county councils — it has a structural incentive to favour fewer, larger unitaries. The PwC model's assumptions are proprietary and not publicly available for scrutiny.

issues.title: CCN is not independent
issues.detail: The County Councils Network represents county councils — the very tier of government that benefits most from fewer unitaries (their geographic footprint is preserved). CCN commissioned PwC specifically to support its preferred model. This is advocacy research, not independent analysis.

issues.title: Proprietary model — no public scrutiny
issues.detail: PwC retains intellectual property over the model. The detailed assumptions, sensitivity analysis, and methodology are not publicly available. This means the £21.2M savings figure for 2 unitaries and the -£11.5M cost figure for 4 unitaries cannot be independently verified or challenged. A model you can't examine is a model you can't trust.

issues.title: Suspiciously linear pattern
issues.detail: The CCN figures show an almost perfectly linear relationship: each additional unitary reduces savings by ~£14-19M. Real-world economics doesn't work this neatly. The academic literature (Andrews & Boyne 2009, Holzer et al. 2009) shows a U-curve, not a straight line — there's an optimal middle range, not an ever-increasing benefit from fewer authorities.

issues.title: Transition costs likely underestimated
issues.detail: UK evidence from Buckinghamshire, Cornwall, and Northamptonshire shows transition costs typically run 20-40% above initial estimates (NAO evidence). PwC's £28.6M for 2 unitaries implies only £14.3M per new authority — significantly below the £18-25M per authority seen in actual reorganisations. The 2-unitary model inherits LCC's Oracle Fusion problems, adding £5-10M+ in IT risk.

issues.title: Savings typically realised at 60-80% of business case
issues.detail: Ernst & Young's 2016 report for DCLG found that actual savings in local government reorganisations typically reach only 60-80% of projected figures within the first 5 years. Applying this to CCN's 2-unitary figure: realistic savings are £12.7-17.0M/year, not £21.2M.

issues.title: Pure cost model — ignores service outcomes
issues.detail: The CCN model treats councils as cost centres, not service providers. It doesn't model the impact on customer satisfaction (LGA surveys show residents in smaller authorities report 10-20% higher satisfaction), recycling rates (districts achieve ~5pp higher rates than unitaries), or planning speed (smaller authorities process applications faster). Cost savings mean nothing if services deteriorate.

independent_model.title: AI DOGE Independent Financial Model
independent_model.subtitle: Built from £12B+ in actual spending data across all 15 Lancashire councils, cross-referenced with academic evidence and UK precedent data

methodology.description: Bottom-up model using actual council expenditure, staffing, reserves and demographic data rather than top-down CCN/PwC estimates. Calibrated against actual outcomes from Buckinghamshire (2020), Dorset (2019), Somerset (2023), North Yorkshire (2023), and Cumbria (2023).
data_sources: AI DOGE spending data: 2,286,000+ transactions, £12B+ across all 15 councils
GOV.UK MHCLG standardised budgets (SeRCOP) for all 15 councils
ONS Census 2021 demographics for all 15 councils via Nomis API
Cross-council supplier analysis and procurement data
Council pay data and senior management costs
self_critique: Census 2021 data is now 5 years old — demographic patterns may have shifted, particularly in migration-driven growth areas

AI DOGE spending data covers district-level spend only for most councils — county-level service costs (social care, education, highways) allocated proportionally by population, not by actual district-level demand
Senior management savings assumed uniform across all scenarios — in practice, smaller authorities may need proportionally more senior staff per head
Social care fragmentation costs are difficult to quantify precisely — our estimates draw on Cumbria and Northamptonshire precedents but Lancashire's specific needs may differ
Transition cost estimates assume competent programme management — LCC's Oracle Fusion experience suggests IT integration risk is higher than average
We cannot model political disruption costs — the years of consultation, lobbying, and transition planning divert officer time from service delivery
Our model does not account for the devolution deal savings that would accompany any unitary structure — these could be significant but are unpredictable

savings_breakdown.description: Where the money comes from and where it goes, for each model

components.description: 15 chief executives (~£140K each), 80+ directors, 200+ senior managers reduced to staffing for 2-5 new authorities
IT, HR, finance, legal, procurement — 15 separate teams consolidated. 18% average saving on combined back-office costs (~£180M total)
Fewer councillors (604 → 160-320), fewer committee structures, fewer elections
15 council HQs reduced to 2-5 main buildings. Office space, depots, civic centres
Bulk purchasing power, contract consolidation. AI DOGE cross-council pricing analysis shows 15-115K% price gaps between councils for identical suppliers
Splitting LCC's £370M+ social care operation. More authorities = higher per-capita cost. Recruitment, commissioning, provider relationships all fragment.
One-off costs spread over 5 years: IT (£12M/authority), redundancy (£8M/authority), programme management (15% of total)

ai_doge_proposals.title: AI DOGE Alternative Proposals
ai_doge_proposals.subtitle: If we were drawing boundaries from scratch based purely on data, demographics, economics and geography — not politics — what would we choose?

proposals.name: AI DOGE Optimal: Two Unitaries (Revised Boundaries)
proposals.description: The 2-unitary model offers by far the strongest financial case. But LCC's proposed North/South split is geographically awkward. AI DOGE proposes an East/West split that better reflects economic geography, travel patterns, and community identity.
proposals.rationale: The M6 motorway is Lancashire's economic spine. Communities west of the M6 (Blackpool, Fylde, Preston, Wyre, Lancaster, Chorley, South Ribble, West Lancs) share a commuter and retail economy oriented toward the motorway corridor and the coast. Communities east (Blackburn, Burnley, Hyndburn, Pendle, Rossendale, Ribble Valley) share industrial heritage, deprivation patterns, and the Pennine geography. An East/West split aligns with economic reality rather than the arbitrary Ribble line.

authorities.name: Western Lancashire
authorities.notes: M6 corridor + coast. Includes Blackpool unitary. Preston as administrative capital. Strong commuter economy, university city (Lancaster), tourism (Blackpool). Largest proposed authority in any model.

authorities.name: Eastern Lancashire
authorities.notes: Pennine Lancashire + Blackburn unitary + Ribble Valley. Shared industrial heritage, deprivation challenges, Asian community ties. Ribble Valley provides rural balance and affluent tax base.

proposals.financial_case: Same 2-authority savings as LCC proposal (~£24.8M/year) but better economic coherence. Eastern Lancashire inherits Blackburn's existing unitary experience (already running social care), reducing transition risk.
proposals.democratic_case: Both authorities would have ~80 councillors (1:5,700-11,400 ratio). Parish/town councils should be empowered as a compensating mechanism for democratic proximity.
proposals.risk: Western Lancashire at 914K is the largest authority in any proposal — risk of diseconomies. But Blackpool's existing unitary infrastructure provides a nucleus.

proposals.name: AI DOGE Balanced: Three Unitaries (Revised)
proposals.description: If the government requires three authorities, this configuration optimises for economic geography while keeping all three above or near 500K.
proposals.rationale: The key weakness of the submitted 3-unitary proposal is the Coastal Lancashire authority (only 493K). Moving Preston into Coastal creates a much stronger Western authority, while Central Lancashire (Chorley, South Ribble, West Lancs) remains viable as a commuter-belt authority.

authorities.name: Western Lancashire
authorities.notes: Coast + university cities. Preston administrative capital. All major tourism and education assets.

authorities.name: Central Lancashire
authorities.notes: M6 commuter belt. Most affluent proposed authority. Below 500K but economically self-sufficient.

authorities.name: Pennine Lancashire
authorities.notes: East Lancashire industrial heartland + Blackburn. Shared deprivation, shared heritage, shared community.

proposals.financial_case: Similar savings to submitted 3-unitary (~£11.2M/year) but all authorities closer to 500K. Central Lancashire below threshold but within exception range (government says 500K is a 'guiding principle' not a hard floor).
proposals.risk: Central Lancashire at 420K below threshold. Government may reject. Ribble Valley residents would prefer Western grouping.

ai_doge_analysis.title: AI DOGE Independent Assessment
ai_doge_analysis.subtitle: Based on £12B+ in spending data, Census 2021 demographics, GOV.UK budgets, academic evidence, and independent financial modelling across all 15 Lancashire councils

assessments.reasoning: The 2-unitary model is the only option that generates transformative annual savings (£24.8M by our independent model, £21.2M by CCN). Both authorities clear the 500K bar. Over 10 years, this saves Lancashire £216M vs the current system. However, South Lancashire at 880K pushes towards the academic diseconomy threshold, and the North/South split doesn't reflect economic geography as well as an East/West split would. The financial case is overwhelming; the governance case is adequate but not ideal.

The 3-unitary model generates meaningful savings (£11.2M/year by our model) while creating authorities in the academic sweet spot of 490-590K. Pennine Lancashire aligns with genuine economic and cultural ties. Coastal Lancashire's 493K population is technically below the 500K threshold but the government has stated exceptions are possible. The main risk is Coastal Lancashire's aging demographics driving up social care costs per head. A credible second-best option financially.

Despite the broadest council support, the economics are poor. Our independent model shows this costs £3.2M more per year (less dramatic than CCN's -£11.5M but still net negative). Over 10 years, taxpayers are £80M worse off. Fylde Coast at 348K with the oldest demographics in Lancashire creates a social care funding crisis. The 6-council coalition looks like district self-preservation dressed up as localism.

Splitting districts at ward level has no recent English precedent. Northern Lancashire at 201K would be England's smallest unitary by a significant margin — too small for efficient social care delivery. Our model shows the highest transition costs (£55M) due to ward-level data splitting, and a net annual cost of £5.8M. This is Blackpool's attempt to dilute its financial difficulties across a larger tax base.

The 80% survey support is compelling, but the 1,600-respondent self-selecting survey is not a representative sample. Our independent model shows this is the worst financial option: -£14.5M/year, costing taxpayers £205M over 10 years. Five social care departments for 1.6M people is fragmentation that academic evidence warns against. However, this model scores highest for democratic proximity — all authorities within the academic optimal range (Andrews & Boyne 2009: 200-400K). The question is whether that democratic benefit is worth £14.5M per year.

ai_doge_analysis.recommendation: AI DOGE's independent financial model — built from £12B+ in actual spending data, not CCN lobbying — confirms that the Two Unitary model is overwhelmingly the best financial option for Lancashire. It saves £24.8M per year, pays back transition costs in 1.3 years, and delivers £216M in net savings over 10 years. No other model comes close. The Three Unitary model is a credible alternative at £11.2M/year savings if the government requires smaller authorities. All 4+ unitary models cost taxpayers MORE than the current system. The money is taxpayers' money — £24.8M per year buys a lot of pothole repairs, social care hours, and library opening times. An AI DOGE East/West boundary revision would further improve the 2-unitary model's economic coherence without sacrificing savings.

key_citations: Andrews, R. & Boyne, G.A. (2009) 'Size, Structure and Administrative Overheads', Urban Studies, 46(4), pp. 739-759 — U-curve: optimal 150-300K, diseconomies above ~500K
Holzer, M. et al. (2009) 'Literature Review on Optimal Municipal Size', Rutgers University — international meta-analysis, optimal range 100-250K
Drew, J., Kortt, M.A. & Dollery, B. (2014) — meta-analysis: economies of scale are service-specific, not universal
Ernst & Young (2016) for DCLG — savings realisation at 60-80% of business case within 5 years
NAO (2019, 2020) Financial Sustainability of Local Authorities — no systematic relationship between authority size and financial sustainability

optimal_population_range.ai_doge_note: The government's 500K threshold is a POLICY choice, not an evidence-based finding. The academic literature actually suggests 200-400K is optimal. Authorities above 500K show diminishing returns. The government chose 500K to create fewer, larger authorities — that's a political decision about devolution deal compatibility, not an economics conclusion.

political_context.title: The Politics Behind the Proposals
political_context.subtitle: Every proposal was submitted by a council with something to gain or lose. Understanding the political motivations is essential.

council_control.note: Won May 2025. LGR would abolish their newly-won majority.

self_interest_analysis.submitter_motivation: LCC submitted the model that most closely preserves its geographic footprint. Reform UK controls LCC (52/84 seats) — they have the strongest institutional incentive to create large authorities where county-level name recognition translates to voter support. However, LGR abolishes LCC regardless of model, so this is about influence over the successor, not self-preservation.

Creates the most councillor seats (5 × ~64 = ~320 vs 2 × ~80 = ~160). Burnley spent £340K+ on LGR consultancy (Socitm, 31ten Consulting) to develop this model. The 80% survey figure comes from a self-selecting survey of Burnley/Pendle residents, not a representative sample. Both councils' leaders would have the best chance of becoming leaders of the new East Lancashire authority — it's their home turf.

The 6 submitting councils (Chorley, Lancaster, Preston, Ribble Valley, South Ribble, West Lancs) created groupings that most closely preserve their existing boundaries. This is collective district self-preservation — the broadest coalition isn't necessarily the most public-spirited, it's the one where the most councils get to keep their geographic identity.

Blackpool is near Section 114 (effective bankruptcy). This model dilutes Blackpool's financial difficulties across a larger tax base by absorbing parts of Wyre and linking to Preston. The ward-level split of Wyre and Ribble Valley primarily serves Blackpool's needs, not those communities.

reform_uk_impact.description: Reform UK is the biggest political loser from LGR. Having just won a landslide at Lancashire County Council (52 of 84 seats in May 2025), LGR abolishes the institution they just captured. No other party faces this dynamic.
key_points: Reform won control of LCC just 9 months before the consultation launched
LGR abolishes LCC regardless of which model is chosen
Reform's county-wide electoral infrastructure doesn't map neatly to any proposed unitary boundary
The government (Labour) is effectively abolishing the council controlled by its main insurgent rival
Reform is challenging the election cancellations in the High Court

key_issues.title: LCC Debt Transfer
key_issues.description: Lancashire CC holds significant borrowing including the VeLTIP bond portfolio (£519M invested, ~£169M current value — a ~£350M paper loss). How this debt is distributed to successor authorities is the single biggest financial risk of reorganisation. GOV.UK criteria state 'no proposal for council debt to be addressed centrally or written off' — all debt stays in Lancashire.

key_issues.title: Dedicated Schools Grant Deficit
key_issues.description: LCC carries a DSG deficit projected to reach £419.9M by 2028/29. This statutory obligation for SEND provision will transfer to successor authorities. In a 2-unitary model, each authority inherits ~£210M of deficit. In a 5-unitary model, the smallest authority (East Lancs, 272K pop) could inherit ~£72M — potentially overwhelming.

key_issues.title: Reserves Depletion
key_issues.description: Combined reserves across all 15 councils total ~£714M but are declining at £27.8M per year. LCC's reserves are falling fastest (-£21.9M/year). By vesting day (April 2028), total reserves could be ~£660M — and much of this is earmarked for specific obligations, leaving limited unallocated reserves for the transition itself.

key_issues.title: Social Care Fragmentation
key_issues.description: LCC currently runs adult social care for 1.2M people with a budget of £370M+. CQC already rates LCC as 'Requires Improvement'. Splitting this service further risks quality deterioration. Academic evidence shows no efficiency gain from fragmenting social care into smaller units — it's driven by need, not population size. More authorities = more commissioning teams, more provider relationships, more recruitment competition.

key_issues.title: Staff TUPE Transfer
key_issues.description: Approximately 30,000+ staff across all 15 councils will need TUPE transfer to successor authorities. Different pay scales, pension schemes, and terms must be harmonised. This is typically the most expensive part of reorganisation — Buckinghamshire spent £4.5M on redundancy alone.

key_issues.title: IT System Consolidation
key_issues.description: 15 councils run different IT systems for revenues, planning, housing, and corporate services. LCC's Oracle Fusion implementation has been plagued with data breaches and payment errors. System consolidation typically costs £12M per new authority (SOCITM estimates). The NAO identifies IT integration as the single largest risk factor in LGR and the most common cause of cost overruns.

key_issues.title: Council Tax Harmonisation
key_issues.description: Band D council tax varies from ~£200 to ~£350 across district councils (before county/police/fire precepts). Harmonisation means some residents pay more, some pay less. The political impact is significant — increases are far more visible than holds. Up to 7 years legally allowed for transition but most new unitaries harmonise within 2-3 years.

precedents.actual_outcome: Often cited as success story. IT integration took 3 years. Savings on track by year 3 but first 2 years consumed by transition costs.
precedents.notes: Single unitary from 4 districts + county. Most comparable to Lancashire's 2-unitary model.

precedents.actual_outcome: Two unitaries — Dorset Council (rural) + BCP (urban). Christchurch residents voted 84% against merger but were overridden.
precedents.notes: Most directly comparable to Lancashire — 2 unitaries from multi-council area.

precedents.actual_outcome: Created from bankrupt county council (Section 114 in 2018). Successor authorities inherited massive debts and depleted reserves. Cautionary tale for LCC's financial problems.
precedents.notes: CAUTIONARY TALE — reorganisation driven by financial failure. Lancashire's LCC has similar risk factors (VeLTIP losses, DSG deficit, Oracle Fusion problems).

precedents.actual_outcome: Largest geographic area of any English unitary. IT integration still ongoing. Savings claims being independently audited.
precedents.notes: Largest single unitary merger. 7 districts + county.

precedents.actual_outcome: Most recent precedent. First 2 years dominated by reorganisation, not service improvement. Redundancy and reserves pooling were the main early impacts.
precedents.notes: 4 districts + county merged into single unitary.

precedents.actual_outcome: Cumberland + Westmorland and Furness. Legacy contracts and IT systems created integration headaches. Transition costs estimated to have exceeded initial projections.
precedents.notes: Split county + 6 districts into 2 unitaries. Geographic similarity to Lancashire (rural + urban mix).
